answers.a: When used within approved limits in foods, calcium disodium EDTA (E385) is not considered harmful; regulators have set an acceptable daily intake and typical exposure is well below it. Excessive intake can bind essential minerals and may cause stomach upset, but this is unlikely from normal food use.

answers.q: is calcium disodium edta bad for you
answers.a: For most people, no—at permitted food levels it’s considered safe and helps protect flavor and color. Very high doses can chelate essential minerals, but such exposures don’t occur from ordinary foods.
No—it's a synthetic additive and contains no milk or lactose.
Yes—it's generally considered vegan because it is chemically synthesized and not derived from animal ingredients.

answers.q: what is calcium disodium edta in food
answers.a: It’s a sequestrant/antioxidant preservative (E385) that binds trace metals like iron and copper to prevent oxidation, off-flavors, and discoloration in foods such as dressings, mayonnaise, canned vegetables, and beverages.
